I agree, I would prefer that the Gradle tool not generate these gitignore files for me.  But the current release does and it makes hacking on Kafka (very slightly) harder.
I am not really a Gradle user, the only reason I installed it was to work on Kafka, so I don't really have much backstory on why it does.

@ijuma Followed the same pattern as what KafkaConsumer#close treats interruption but also explicitly added an if clause to check InterruptedException since `firstException` would be set to it explicitly in  KafkaProducer#close. Please have a review on that. Thanks.

cc @hachikuji

@hachikuji @ijuma Can you take a look? Thank you...

At the moment, consumer handles transient broker failures during fetch, but not during rebalance. If metadata request before rebalance had returned LEADER_NOT_AVAILABLE, the subsequent rebalance simply skips assignment and the next metadata request only happens on metadata expiry. This PR schedules a refresh to occur after refresh backoff interval so that rebalance is triggered sooner when leader is known. Since topic/partition errors returned in consumer metadata responses correspond to topics/partitions explicitly subscribed/assigned, I am hoping the extra requests are reasonable.
This makes sense to me and, in my experience, the current behaviour surprises people. Let's see what @hachikuji says though.

@guozhangwang based on my investigation into increasing the session timeout on rebalance. There is an optimization that can be made to the `StickyTaskAssignor` that means that active tasks won't move during bounces.

This is fine for reuse, but just to clarify we won't be supporting this as public API and it can be changed in the future. But the ability to convert the schema to JSON is generally useful so we can make this public but unstable API.
